reg:regulation.reg:acttitle: Court Rules Act and Small Claims Act
reg:regulation.reg:title: Small Claims Rules

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Payment order
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a judge decides that one party must pay money to another party, the judge must make a payment order at the end of the trial.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Payment deferral
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: After making a payment order, the judge must ask

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the debtor requires time to pay, and
if so, when the debtor proposes to pay.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Creditor to be consulted
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the debtor asks for time to pay, the judge must ask the creditor if the creditor agrees with the debtor's proposal.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If the creditor agrees
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the creditor agrees with the proposal, the judge may order a payment schedule requiring the debt to be paid by a set date or by instalments.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If the creditor does not agree
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the creditor does not agree with the proposal, the judge may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: order a payment hearing, or
order a payment schedule.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: No collection while payments being made
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The creditor may not take any other steps to collect the debt as long as the debtor is making payments in accordance with the payment schedule.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If no order is made
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If no order is made under subrule (5), the debt is payable immediately and the creditor may collect the debt by taking any of the steps listed in subrule (11).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a judge orders a payment hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a judge orders a payment hearing under subrule (5), the creditor may not take any other steps to collect payment until after the payment hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Registrar's payment order
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The registrar may make a payment order.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Registrar may make some orders without a hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The registrar may make the following orders without a hearing:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a payment order in the amount agreed to plus expenses under Rule 20 (2) (a) and (b) and any interest the claimant is entitled to if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the defendant agrees to pay all or part of a claim on a reply, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order establishing a payment schedule if the defendant proposes or requests a payment schedule in the reply and the claimant consents to the order;
an order issuing a summons to a defendant to attend a payment hearing if a proposed payment schedule is not agreed to by the claimant.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How payment may be collected
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To collect payment due under a payment order (Form 10), a creditor may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: ask the registrar to issue an order for seizure and sale under subrule (12);
ask for a payment hearing under Rule 12 (3);
ask a judge or registrar to issue a garnishing order under the Court Order Enforcement Act;
ask for a default hearing under Rule 13 (2), if the debtor defaults in making payments under a payment schedule;
enforce the order by any other means permitted by law.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Address for service form
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A creditor who wishes to collect payment under subrule (11) and has not yet filed an address for service (Form 38) must, in addition to doing anything set out in subrule (11), file an address for service and serve a copy on each of the other parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When an order for seizure and sale may be issued
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The registrar may issue an order for seizure and sale (Form 11) if a creditor

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: completes the form, following the instructions on the form, and
files it at the registry, together with a copy of the relevant decision, certificate or order.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How long an order for seizure and sale is in effect
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If an order for seizure and sale has not been enforced within 12 months after it was issued, it expires but the creditor may ask the registrar to issue another one.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a debtor does not obey a payment schedule
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a debtor defaults on the payments under a payment schedule,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the balance of the money required to be paid under the payment order becomes due immediately, and
the creditor may collect the entire amount by taking any of the steps listed in subrule (11).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a decision is reserved
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a payment order is made in the absence of the parties because the judge reserved the decision,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the creditor may take any of the steps listed in subrule (11), and
the debtor may ask for a payment hearing under Rule 12 (10).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a payment order is made in favour of a young person
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a payment order is made in favour of a person under 19 years of age, a judge may order the amount payable under the order to be paid to the Public Guardian and Trustee for that person.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Collection while payment hearing outstanding
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a summons to a payment hearing has been filed, the creditor may not take any other steps to collect payment until

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the payment hearing has concluded, or
the summons has been withdrawn or cancelled.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Collection after warrant for arrest ordered
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a warrant is issued for the arrest of a debtor or of an officer, director or employee of a corporate debtor, the creditor may take any steps to collect payment due under a payment order as if a payment hearing had concluded.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Purpose of a payment hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The purpose of a payment hearing is to allow a judge or justice to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: assess the debtor's ability to pay, and
consider whether a payment schedule should be ordered.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Parties may request a payment hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A payment hearing will be held if it is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: requested by the creditor under subrule (3),
requested by the debtor under subrule (10), or
ordered by the judge under Rule 11 (5) (a).

bcl:division.bcl:text: If a Creditor Asks for a Payment Hearing

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How a creditor asks for a payment hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To ask for a payment hearing, a creditor must complete a summons to a payment hearing (Form 12), following the instructions on the form, and file it at the registry at least 14 days before the date of the payment hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When a creditor is not allowed to ask for a payment hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A creditor who has an order for seizure and sale outstanding against the debtor may not ask for a payment hearing without the permission of a judge (see Rule 16 (7)).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If the debtor is a corporation
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the debtor is a corporation, an officer, director or employee of the corporation may be summoned to the payment hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If the debtor is a partnership
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the debtor is a partnership, a partner may be summoned to the payment hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Service of the summons
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person named in a summons to a payment hearing must be served by leaving the summons, together with the following documents, with the person at least 14 days before the date of the payment hearing:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a blank supporting materials cover sheet (Form 39);
a blank statement of finances (Form 40), unless the debtor is a corporation or a partnership.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Summons may be cancelled if wrong person summoned
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person who is served with a summons to a payment hearing may apply to a judge (see Rule 16 (7)) who may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: cancel the summons if the person is not the right person to provide information on behalf of the debtor, and
direct the registrar to issue a new summons to someone who is the right person to provide the information.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What a person summoned by a creditor must file
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person summoned by a creditor to a payment hearing must file the following records and other things at least 7 days before the date of the payment hearing:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a supporting materials cover sheet (Form 39), unless the person is not required to file any other records or other things under this subrule;
a statement of finances (Form 40), unless the debtor is a corporation or a partnership;
any other records or other things required by the summons;
any other records or other things on which the person intends to rely at the payment hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What a person summoned by a creditor must serve
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person summoned by a creditor to a payment hearing must serve on the creditor the records and other things filed under subrule (9) (b), (c) or (d) at least 2 business days before the date of the payment hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Debtor must update statement of finances if necessary
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If there is a significant change to the debtor's finances after filing a statement of finances and before the payment hearing, the debtor must, before the start of the payment hearing,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file a revised statement of finances (Form 40), with a supporting materials cover sheet (Form 39), and
serve the revised statement of finances on the creditor.

bcl:division.bcl:text: If a Debtor Asks for a Payment Hearing

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How a debtor asks for a payment hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To ask for a payment hearing, a debtor must complete the following forms, following the instructions on the forms, and file them at the registry at least 14 days before the date of the payment hearing:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a notice of payment hearing (Form 13);
a supporting materials cover sheet (Form 39), unless the debtor is a corporation or a partnership;
a statement of finances (Form 40), unless the debtor is a corporation or a partnership.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Address for service form
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A debtor who wishes to ask for a payment hearing and has not yet filed an address for service (Form 38) must file an address for service and serve a copy on each of the other parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Service of notice on creditor
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The debtor must serve on the creditor the notice and the statement of finances, if applicable, at least 14 days before the date of the payment hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What a debtor must file if the debtor asks for a payment hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A debtor must file any records or other things on which the debtor intends to rely at the payment hearing and that were not filed under subrule (10), together with a supporting materials cover sheet (Form 39), at least 7 days before the date of the payment hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What a debtor must serve if the debtor asks for a payment hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A debtor must serve on the creditor any records or other things filed under subrule (11.1) at least 2 business days before the date of the payment hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Debtor must update statement of finances if necessary
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If there is a significant change to the debtor's finances after filing a statement of finances and before the payment hearing, the debtor must, before the start of the payment hearing,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file a revised statement of finances (Form 40), with a supporting materials cover sheet (Form 39), and
serve the revised statement of finances on the creditor.

bcl:division.bcl:text: If a Judge Orders a Payment Hearing

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What a person must file if a judge orders a payment hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person ordered by a judge under Rule 11 (5) (a) to attend a payment hearing must file the following records and other things at least 7 days before the date of the payment hearing:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a supporting materials cover sheet (Form 39), unless the person is not required to file any other records or other things under this subrule;
a statement of finances (Form 40), unless the debtor is a corporation or a partnership;
any other records or other things required by the order;
any other records or other things on which the person intends to rely at the payment hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What a person must serve if a judge orders a payment hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person ordered by a judge under Rule 11 (5) (a) to attend a payment hearing must serve on the creditor the records and other things filed under subrule (11.4) (b), (c) or (d) at least 2 business days before the date of the payment hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Debtor must update statement of finances if necessary
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If there is a significant change to the debtor's finances after filing a statement of finances and before the payment hearing, the debtor must, before the start of the payment hearing,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file a revised statement of finances (Form 40), with a supporting materials cover sheet (Form 39), and
serve the revised statement of finances on the creditor.

bcl:division.bcl:text: What Happens at a Payment Hearing

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What happens at a payment hearing?
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: At any payment hearing under these rules, evidence may be heard about any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the income and assets of the debtor;
the debts owed to and by the debtor;
any assets that the debtor has disposed of since the claim arose;
the means that the debtor has, or may have in the future, of paying the amount owed.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: A payment schedule may be ordered
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: After hearing the evidence and submissions by the parties, the judge or justice may order a payment schedule specifying

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the date by which the debt must be paid, or
the amounts and dates of the instalments.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a creditor does not attend
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a creditor does not attend a payment hearing, the judge or justice may hold the hearing, cancel it or postpone it.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a person summoned or ordered to attend does not attend
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a creditor asks, a judge or justice may issue a warrant (Form 9) for the arrest of a person who does not attend a payment hearing and who was

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: served with a summons to attend, or
present before a judge or justice when the judge or justice ordered the person to attend.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Debtor may swear or affirm — statement of finances
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a debtor has filed a statement of finances (Form 40), the judge or justice may direct the debtor to swear or affirm to the truth of the contents of the statement of finances at the payment hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When a creditor may ask for a default hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A creditor may ask the registrar for a default hearing if the debtor does not obey a payment schedule that was

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: made in an order under Rule 7 (14) (c) (at a settlement conference),
made in an order under Rule 7.5 (14) (b) (at a trial conference),
made under Rule 11 (4) (at the trial),
made under Rule 12 (13) (at a payment hearing), or
changed under Rule 17 (3).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How a creditor asks for a default hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To ask for a default hearing, the creditor must complete a summons (Form 14), following the instructions on the form, and file it at the registry.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If the debtor is a corporation
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the debtor is a corporation, an officer, director or employee of the corporation may be summoned to the default hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If the debtor is a partnership
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the debtor is a partnership, a partner may be summoned to the default hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Service of the summons
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person named in a summons to a default hearing must be served by a court bailiff or sheriff leaving the summons with the person at least 14 days before the date of the default hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What must be served with the summons
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The court bailiff or sheriff who serves a person under subrule (5) must also provide the person with

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a blank supporting materials cover sheet (Form 39), and
a blank statement of finances (Form 40), unless the person being served is a corporation or a partnership.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What a person who is served with a summons must file
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person who is served with a summons to a default hearing must file the following records and other things at the registry at least 7 days before the date of the default hearing:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a supporting materials cover sheet (Form 39), unless the person is not required to file any other records or other things under this subrule;
a statement of finances (Form 40), unless the debtor is a corporation or a partnership;
any other records or other things required by the summons;
any other records or other things on which the person intends to rely at the default hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What a person who is served with a summons must serve
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person who is served with a summons to a default hearing must serve on the creditor the records and other things filed under subrule (6) (b), (c) or (d) at least 2 business days before the date of the default hearing.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Debtor must update statement of finances if necessary
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If there is a significant change to the debtor's finances after filing a statement of finances and before the default hearing, the debtor must, before the start of the default hearing

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file a revised statement of finances (Form 40), with a supporting materials cover sheet (Form 39), and
serve the revised statement of finances on the creditor.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What the judge may do at a default hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: At a default hearing, the judge may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: confirm the terms of a payment schedule or other order, or
change the terms of a payment schedule or other order in any manner that the judge thinks is fair to the debtor and the creditor.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Judge may order debtor imprisoned
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The judge may issue a warrant (Form 15) requiring the debtor to be imprisoned for a specified period of not more than 20 days if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the debtor has not obeyed a payment schedule, and
the debtor's explanation, or failure to give an explanation, of why the payment schedule has not been obeyed is considered by the judge to amount to contempt of court.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a person does not attend
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the creditor asks, the judge may issue a warrant (Form 9) for the arrest of a person who does not attend a default hearing and who was

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: served with a summons to attend, or
present before a judge when the judge ordered the person to attend.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Debtor may swear or affirm — statement of finances
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a debtor has filed a statement of finances (Form 40), the judge may direct the debtor to swear or affirm to the truth of the contents of the statement of finances at the default hearing.

bcl:rule.bcl:text: Warrant of Arrest for Not Attending Court

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of arrest
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a warrant of arrest is issued under Rule 9 (7), 12 (15) or 13 (9), the registrar must serve the person named in the warrant with a notice of arrest.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What a person may do after receiving a notice of arrest
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person who is served with a notice of arrest may contact the registrar to arrange to attend court voluntarily.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Sheriff or peace officer may arrest
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a person who is served with a notice of arrest does not arrange, within 7 days after the date of service, to attend court voluntarily, a sheriff or peace officer may arrest the person.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Sheriff or peace officer must bring arrested person to court
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A sheriff or peace officer who arrests a person under subrule (3) must promptly bring the person to court.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What a judge or justice may do
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a person attends court voluntarily under subrule (2) or under arrest under subrule (3), the judge or justice may release the person and may order the person to attend on another date.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Cancellation of warrant
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a person named in a warrant attends court voluntarily under subrule (5), the warrant is cancelled.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a person fails to appear as ordered
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a person has been ordered under subrule (5) to appear on another date and the person does not appear as ordered, a judge may issue a warrant (Form 9) for the immediate arrest of the person.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How long the warrant is in effect
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A warrant of arrest remains in force for 12 months from the date of its issue, but at the end of that period it expires and no one may be arrested under it.

bcl:rule.bcl:text: If a Warrant of Imprisonment Is Issued

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Imprisonment
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a warrant of imprisonment is issued under Rule 13 (8) or 19 (1), a sheriff or peace officer may arrest the person named in the warrant and deliver that person to the director of a correctional centre referred to in the warrant.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How long the warrant is in effect
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A warrant of imprisonment remains in force for 12 months from the date of its issue, but at the end of that period it expires and no one may be imprisoned under it.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Debtor may pay
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a warrant of imprisonment is issued under Rule 13 (8), the debtor may pay the amount stated in the warrant to the registrar or to a sheriff, peace officer or warden who has custody of the person.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What the registrar does after receiving payment
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the money is paid to the registrar, the registrar must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: issue a receipt for the payment and then pay that amount to the creditor, and
if the debtor has not yet been arrested, cancel the warrant of imprisonment.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Release after payment
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A sheriff, peace officer or warden must release a debtor imprisoned under a warrant of imprisonment if the debtor

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: pays the amount stated in the warrant, or
shows a registrar's receipt for payment of the amount.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Money to be given to the creditor
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A sheriff, peace officer or warden who receives money under this rule must forward the money to the registrar for payment to the creditor named in the warrant of imprisonment.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Imprisonment does not cancel the debt
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Imprisonment under these rules does not cancel the debt or any right of the creditor to take steps to collect it.
